text:
Exercise:
Open your terminal, navigate to your Actualize folder
Make a new folder called practice-javascript
```mkdir practice-javascript
cd practice-javascript```
Make a new file called test.js
```touch test.js```
Open the folder in VSCode
```code .```
Paste in the following code (which has mistakes):
```my_variable = 3

  console.log(my_variable)```
Use the Setup: VSCode linter for JavaScript guide to install a linter and formatter in your text editor


If you finish early, you can practice writing some javascript (you can run your code in the terminal using `node test.js`)

If you want your code to auto format when you save, *add* this line to your settings.json in VSCode (access settings.json with `cmd + shift + p` and `Open User Settings JSON`
```"[javascript]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode"
  },```

text:
Exercise:
• Open your terminal, navigate to your Actualize folder
• Clone the js-lotr exercise:
```git clone <https://github.com/actualize-daytime-2022-12-04/js-lotr.git>```
```cd js-lotr```

• Open the index.html file in your browser (if it opens in Safari, copy the url to Google Chrome)
```open index.html```

• In your Google Chrome browser, open the web inspector using the keyboard shortcut CMD OPT J

• In your terminal, open your text editor
```code .```

• Write your code in `scripts/tasks.js`. Read each task and write the solution code for each where it says “WRITE YOUR CODE HERE”
• After your group agrees each task is complete, uncomment the test function and refresh the browser. Check out the console.
• If you get stuck for a while, you can reference the `solutions.js` file to keep making progress
Bonus: Check out the `tests.js` file to see how the tests are written.

Super Bonus: Check out the `domEvents.js` file, then read up on DOM Manipulation: <https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_htmldom_document.asp>.
See if you can change a function to do something different to the DOM!

Some reference javascript code: <https://gist.github.com/peterxjang/cdfa5184459de13bde8db504f2607a20>

attachments.text: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

text:
Exercise:
Practice JavaScript!
• Option 1: Continue with the js-lotr exercises
• Option 2: Complete the problems in this gist: <https://gist.github.com/peterxjang/cdfa5184459de13bde8db504f2607a20> 
• Option 3: Use your deliberate practice skills spreadsheet to practice specific problems

elements.text: Option 1: Continue with the js-lotr exercises
Option 2: Complete the problems in this gist:
Option 3: Use your deliberate practice skills spreadsheet to practice specific problems

text: Example whiteboarding problem: Write a function that takes in an array of numbers and returns the largest number.

elements.text: Example whiteboarding problem: Write a function that takes in an array of numbers and returns the largest number.

text:
```numbers = [2,3,1,9,3,7]
max = 0

index = 0
while index < numbers.length
   if numbers[index] > max
      max = numbers[index]
   end
   index += 1
end

p max```
